abstracts.cdata!:
The policy framework of the Agricultural
            Services and Producer Organizations Project stipulates, in
            accordance with the Bank's rules and procedures, that
            cultural heritage sites, natural habitats, and indigenous
            populations, will be protected; thus, subprojects affecting
            any of the above, will not be financed by the project.
            However, some subprojects concerning small scale irrigation,
            flood protection activities, infrastructure works regarding
            soil conservation, as well as infrastructure linked to
            fisheries activities, and water protection, may potentially
            require resettlement. Based on the country's legal
            framework, and the Bank's resettlement rules and
            regulations, consultations with local communities will be
            conducted, to inform project affected people (PAP) on their
            rights, and alternatives for resettlement. This resettlement
            action plan (RAP) sets the framework to guide relocation as
            needed, and aims to improve, or at least restore the living
            conditions of PAP. Compensation will be either in the form
            of land replacement, which includes loss of houses and
            structures, as well as agricultural and crop losses
            (financial credit will be available to cover equipment
            losses), or, as cash compensation, to be paid in local
            currency, adjusted to inflation costs. Assistance will
            further include moving expenses, various modes of
            transportation, as well as new employment opportunities.
            Finally, monitoring criteria will ensure the appropriate
            implementation of this RAP, and grievance mechanisms should
            ensure any conflict resolution.
